fields.description:
*Assessment*

Eucalyptus DNS binds to a specific interface, which causes issues in certain topologies.  This causes issues when --bind-addr is used to shift Eucalyptus component communication to an internal network (in this case, there are two network interfaces on each machine that runs a Eucalyptus component).  Since Eucalyptus DNS binds to a specific interface, this keeps Eucalyptus DNS from responding to both instance requests as well as internet DNS requests since both instance DNS and DNS domain delegation is being used.

*Signs*

Looking at a CLC/Walrus machine, all the Eucalyptus user-facing service endpoints are bound to 0.0.0.0 except Eucalyptus DNS:

{code}
$ $ sudo netstat -pln | grep LISTEN | grep 877
tcp        0      0 10.104.1.216:8779           0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      32382/eucalyptus-cl
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:8773                0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      32382/eucalyptus-cl
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:8777                0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      32535/postgres
tcp        0      0 :::8777                     :::*                        LISTEN      32535/postgres
....
{code}

{code}
$ sudo netstat -pln | grep LISTEN | grep ":53"
tcp        0      0 10.104.1.216:53             0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      32382/eucalyptus-cl
{code}

*Actions*

* Stand up and register Eucalyptus components (only need CLC, Walrus, CC and SC) using the --bind-addr option
* Enable Eucalyptus DNS
* View netstat information to see what interface Eucalyptus DNS is listening on

*Workaround*

No workaround known at this time.
fields.summary: Eucalyptus DNS binds to a specific interface which causes issues in certain topologies

comments.body: a specific DNS plugin will be created for the resolver issue for the ECC.  This could also be done for other specific topologies if they arise prior to 4.0

I believe a workaround is available. You should be able to use iptables to redirect queries received on the public interface, to the bind-addr, e.g.

iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $PUBLIC_IFACE -p tcp -m tcp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination $BIND_ADDR:53
iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $PUBLIC_IFACE -p udp -m udp --dport 53 -j DNAT --to-destination $BIND_ADDR:53
[~chuck] , [~spark],  Is this a duplicate/related issue to https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-8528
[~mmunn1], yes this is a duplicate of EUCA-8528... Per discussion with [~nurmi], he was told this would be resolved with 4.0 service separation but couldn't 100% confirm the case.
[~spark], correct.  It would be helpful if Eucalyptus DNS was independently configurable - to listen on a particular interface or all interfaces.  Apologies for the late response.  Hope this helps.

[~hspencer] To clarify:  What you are asking for here is a new user configurable "boolean" dns property to switch between listening on "all" interfaces or the "specific" interface.  You are not asking for new property for the user to pass in a user defined "interface" correct?

[~mmunn1], 

What I think would be cool is the following:

* By default, Eucalyptus DNS listens on the interface that is set on the VNET_PUBINTERFACE on the CLC's eucalyptus.conf
* For specific configuration, the cloud property could be changed by the cloud administrator to accept the following:
** specific interface(s) that exists on the CLC machine (i.e. this can be single or multi-valued)
** the keyword "any"

My thought here is that once the cloud administrator sets up Eucalyptus, starts to the CLC, and then begins to configure Eucalyptus DNS, there is the established default configuration.  From there, if they want to change the default, the cloud property can be used to define the interface(s) that Eucalyptus DNS should listen on - whether that be a single (e.g. "em1"), multiple (e.g. "em1 em2") or "any".  Typically, with DNS servers, system administrators can set DNS to listen to specific IPv4 address(es), or "any".  I think for a first pass, that would be good.  If we want to match more like other DNS servers and use IPv4 addresses instead of interfaces, that would be fine as well, but I think we should do whatever works for how our DNS server is designed.

Does that help?  [~spark], does this make sense?

I think "any" would be a waste of effort in the context of a
Eucalyptus CLC; I can't imagine the use case. A cloud property that
allows me to specify the bind address or interface, defaulting to
VNET_PUBINTERFACE, would suffice.

On Wed, Feb 19, 2014 at 10:39 PM, Harold Spencer Jr. (JIRA)
[~spark] So would the property "dns_interface"  be an IP address or an interface name i.e. "em1"?  In DNSControl.initialize() we use an InetAddress to create the listeners?

I think an address is easier to code (although Euca only supports one
platform) and more useful (when multiple addresses are configured on an
interface).

But you would be solving the problem I had either way.
On 20 Feb 2014 10:05 PM, "Michael Munn (JIRA)" <

[~mmunn1] I think it's better to throw exceptions in that case. When the hander throws exception, there's no change to the property. I think there's a way to restart the tcp/udp listener without restarting clc, but if that involves too much code change I think it's fine that we require clc restart.

Code Review Request : EUCA-7758 Eucalyptus DNS binds to a specific interface which causes issues in certain topologies

branch : dev/mmunn1/EUCA-7758

diff :  git show --color 5f0dd5fdd047dd2766251b07bd8c26b0ba721b34

Summary: Eucalyptus DNS binds to a specific interface which causes issues in certain topologies

Solution: make dns bind to 0.0.0.0 by default and create a configurable property "dns_listen_address" to allow users to configure dns listeners to a specific address. dns.dns_listener_address is  checked for format and reach-ability if either fails an error is logged and the property is not changed.

Unit test with fix:

1)  sudo netstat -pln | grep LISTEN | grep ":53"  
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:53                  0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      17940/eucalyptus-cl

2)  set dns listeners to a specific address:
    a) euca-modify-property -p dns.dns_listener_address=10.111.5.72
    b) sudo netstat -pln | grep LISTEN | grep ":53"   
tcp        0      0 10.111.5.72:53              0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      17940/eucalyptus-cl

Thx Mike

There was regression found while investigating https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-8855.
As a result of fix to EUCA-8855, the default binding address is not 0.0.0.0/0 but address returned by Internets.localHostAddrss().

java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:744) Error(ModifyPropertyValueType): Cannot assign requested address {code} Also I have one small request, can we change the property description that shows up via "euca-describe-properties -v " to explicitly say an ipv4 address in a.b.c.d format only, if that is what should be given as input? This would help remove confusion for folks who would try to add a CIDR value to the IP etc.
[~dshekhawat] Yes that could be, I noticed the 10.104.1.212 in the debug output as well.
Thanks [~mmunn1]  for your quick help!
We should verify that this works in an HA configuration. I do not see how specifying an IP address is possible as the DNS service runs on both cloud controllers.

If we need to make changes here I'm happy to take this issue as part of the work for EUCA-9122. For EUCA-9122 we also need to ensure we are listening on both the detected (--bind-addr) and the configured interfaces to support both cloud internal and external DNS.
Thanks [~sjones], it would be really appreciated if we can make this work in HA configuration. Please let me know if you need any help from my side.

The dns.dns_listener_address property is replaced with dns.dns_listener_address_match which is a comma separated list of CIDRs. On each host running a DNS service listeners will be started on any addresses matching a CIDR.

{code}
dns.dns_listener_address_match = [CIDR]*
{code}

There can be multiple listeners on a host and this can (for example) support both public facing and internal DNS clients.

CIDR values in the regular format (X.X.X.X/X) are supported and the trailing "/X" is optional, defaulting to "/32". Examples of valid CIDRs are 10.20.30.0/24 or 10.20.30.40.

A listener will always be run on the default address (the "\--bind-addr" when specified), the configuration property allows additional listeners to be configured. 

See also EUCA-9122, which defines configuration properties that can be used to control which IPs are returned when services are run on hosts with multiple interfaces.

Here's the confirmed behavior of the DNS listener binding:
1) DNS service always listen on default (web service) address (bind-addr when specified) regardless of property change.
2) By default, the property is set empty, which means DNS service will listen on only default address.
3) Additional addresses can be set in CIDR format and DNS start listening when the machine has interface matching CIDR.
4) The change is effective within a few seconds, without service restart.

That sounds like a great balancing of conflicting use cases. Nice!
